newsitem.title: THAILAND: PRESS DIGEST - Thai newspapers - Jan 28.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Thai newspapers - Jan 28.

text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Thai press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

TOP STORIES - Corruption allegations will be raised by the opposition in a parliamentary motion on the government's actions in the Nong Ngu Hao airport affair. Jurin Laksanavisit, the Democrat MP who chairs the opposition co-ordinating committee, says the motion will seek explanations from the prime minister and other officials. Uncertainty over the project has damaged the country's image and caused confusion among investors, he says. (BANGKOK POST)

- The government has set up seven committees to address more than 100 problems presented by thousands of villagers who have gathered outside Government House. The committees were set up as a result of yesterday's meeting between core members of the protest group and government representatives. However, the leaders of the Assembly of the Poor, which organised the protest, say the villagers will continue to camp outside Government House until concrete action is taken. (THE NATION, BANGKOK POST)

- Prime Minister Chavalit Yongchaiyudh has pledged not to interfere with police investigation into allegations that some members of the current cabinet violated the election law in the November 17 vote. Chavalit made the statement in response to news reports that he was among the cabinet members whose names appeared on the PollWatch list of alleged law-breakers. (BANGKOK POST) + + + +

- The government's plan to rescue the sagging economy by introducing budget cuts totalling 50 billion baht has appeared to suffer a major setback when figures released for the first quarter of the current fiscal year showed the deficit has already reached 53.7 billion baht. Sources say that senior officials from the Finance Ministry, Fiscal Policy Office, the Budget Bureau and the National Economic and Social Development Board will meet today to arrive at further budget cuts for projects slated for the 1997 fiscal year. (THE NATION)

- The Japanese government will be asked to provide support in four main investment areas during next month's trip to Tokyo by the Prime Minister's Advisory Committee on Economic and Foreign Affairs. One area which support will be requested is greater investment in both large and medium-size infrastructure projects, and in the automotive, electricity and electronics industries. The other three areas are the second Mekong Bridge project in Mukdaharn province, manpower and human resource development, and marketing and technology development. (BUSINESS DAY)

- Siam Cement Plc plans to invest a total of 6.8 billion baht to introduce several new construction products, as well as improving domestic distribution and expanding abroad. Outside of Thailand, the building materials group now has seven projects in five Asian countries. (BANGKOK POST)
